title: The multiple LAYERS of childhood adversity
descriptions:
The grant proposal titled "The multiple LAYERS of childhood adversity" aims to establish a comprehensive data infrastructure for analyzing the life course impact of various layers of childhood adversity in a cohort of 2 million individuals spanning three generations. This interdisciplinary project will combine expertise from data science, epidemiology, econometrics, and systems science within a complex systems framework to explore the transgenerational health inequalities rooted in childhood experiences.

The project will investigate the long-lasting effects of multiple forms of adversity, including biological, health, social, neighborhood, and environmental factors. By shifting the current literature focus towards understanding intersecting layers of adversity, the research aims to identify patterns, mechanisms of generation, and dynamics of change in adverse childhood experiences.

Through a real-world policy data lab, the project will integrate nationwide policies and conduct simulations to inform evidence-based interventions targeting children and families in need of support. Ultimately, this research seeks to redirect attention towards the multifaceted nature of childhood adversity and provide insights to guide policy decisions and interventions aimed at improving the well-being of individuals across generations.

The grant proposal, titled "The multiple LAYERS of childhood adversity," aims to establish a comprehensive data infrastructure for analyzing the impact of various layers of childhood adversity across three generations, involving 2 million individuals. This interdisciplinary project will merge data science, epidemiology, econometrics, and systems science within a complex systems framework to investigate the long-lasting effects of adversity on health inequalities, particularly focusing on intersecting biological, health, social, neighborhood, and environmental factors.

The initiative will delve beyond the current literature's emphasis on social adversity, seeking to understand patterns, mechanisms of generation, and dynamics of change in adversity over time. By integrating real-world policy data and conducting simulations, the research aims to redirect attention towards addressing multiple layers of adversity and identifying targets for support, particularly children and families.

Through this innovative approach, the project seeks to provide valuable insights into how childhood adversity influences health disparities across generations, paving the way for evidence-based interventions and policy recommendations to mitigate the impact of adversity on vulnerable populations. Ultimately, this grant proposal holds the potential to drive significant advancements in the field of childhood adversity research and contribute to the well-being of individuals and communities.

The grant proposal "The multiple LAYERS of childhood adversity" aims to establish a unified data infrastructure for life course analyses of childhood adversity in a cohort of 2 million individuals spanning three generations. This interdisciplinary project combines data science, epidemiology, econometrics, and systems science within a complex systems framework to explore the long-lasting effects of multiple forms of childhood adversity across intersecting layers such as biological, health, social, neighborhood, and environmental factors.

By shifting the focus from solely social adversity to a more comprehensive understanding of adversity, the project seeks to uncover patterns, mechanisms of generation, and dynamics of change in the impact of childhood adversity. The integration of real-world policy data and simulations will enable the identification of targets for support, particularly focusing on children and families.

Through this research, the project aims to redirect the focus of existing literature towards the multiple layers of childhood adversity, ultimately contributing to the development of more effective interventions and policies to address health inequalities established in childhood and transmitted across generations. This grant proposal represents a unique opportunity to advance our understanding of the complex interplay of factors shaping childhood experiences and their long-term consequences on health and well-being.
